speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate this opportunity to take part in the Throne Speech debate to comment on the Government's agenda as well as to talk about what it plans to do and to outline some of those things that the Government does not mention.
As has been noted several times in the debate, the emphasis in the Throne Speech was on consensus and conciliation. While this is commendable in some respects, it also brings some of us some concern. For example, it was stated in the Throne Speech that:
Over time, mutual confidence and a sense of shared responsibility for our national economy must lead to consensus on even more basic issues: how to share the benefits of economic growth, how to share the burdens of economic adjustment, how to preserve the integrity of our unique natural environment, and how to ensure that the ideal of social justice is pursued through programs that meet contemporary needs and circumstances.
Consensus on issues such as these can take a very long time to develop. In the meantime, the unemployed and the working poor are bearing most of the burden and receiving very few of the benefits of technological change and the whole process of change in which we find ourselves.
A report put out two months ago by the National Anti-Poverty Organization points out that between 1981 and 1983 there has been a 22 per cent increase in the number of Canadians who must live below the poverty line. In 1981 there were 3.5 million Canadians living below the poverty line. By 1983 that had increased by some 800,000, to 4.3 million Canadians living below the poverty line.
The question that I think we in the House must address is: how long will these people have to wait while we develop a new
consensus? The thought which has occurred to me as 1 looked at some of the measures that the Government has taken is that perhaps the new consensus is already developing to the effect that it is necessary to have more poor people in order to keep wages down and keep Canadians from expecting too high a standard of living.
It is worth while spending a few minutes asking how we develop a consensus. For example, today we have a generally shared consensus in the House about medicare. Even the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) has referred to it as a sacred trust. However, that consensus on medicare did not always exist. That consensus did not exist 20 years ago when medicare in Saskatchewan was established over bitter opposition. It was because leaders like Tommy Douglas and Woodrow Lloyd and the CCF government of Saskatchewan were prepared to risk their political lives on the issue of medicare that medicare was established. Over the years, its value to the Canadian people has been proved, so that now it is generally regarded, even by the Prime Minister, as a sacred trust.
That consensus did not come by sitting around a round table and debating. There had to be leadership. As we work toward a new consensus, it is not enough for the Government to sit back on the sidelines and host summit conferences. It must take some action to ensure that the poor and unemployed, those at the lower end of the income scale, do not get all the burden of industrial change and none of the benefits.
The Throne Speech also stated that the generous co-operation of the provinces:
-is also needed to honour the commitment to Canada's aboriginal peoples contained in the Constitution Act of 1982. For these peoples, as for all Canadians, the high expectations that attended the act of patriation must not be disappointed.
There is no question that some of the provinces had a very mean-spirited approach to aboriginal rights in the last two constitutional conferences. There must be a more generous approach, but it is not enough for the Prime Minister to call for generous co-operation. If we are going to honour our commitments to the aboriginal peoples of Canada, then the federal Government must show leadership.
Where does the Government stand on constitutional entrenchment of the right of aboriginal peoples for self-government? Is it prepared to take an active advocacy role on behalf of aboriginal peoples? I believe that we all recognize that the new Government has a tremendous reservoir of popular support. Is it prepared to risk some of that support? Is it prepared to spend some of its popularity capital in an attempt to lead public opinion on this question of aboriginal rights? Is it prepared to put pressure on the provinces so they will act

November 19, 1984
The Address-Mr. Manly
generously, or is it simply prepared to issue a nice call for the provinces to act generously in the hope they will respond?
[DOT] (U10)
I am concerned about the phrasing in this particular section. It talks about the commitment to Canada's aboriginal peoples which is contained in the Constitution Act of 1982. There is no mention in that reference to the fact that we are talking about aboriginal rights. It suggests that the commitment in the Constitution Act of 1982 was perhaps an act of generosity on the part of the Government of Canada at the time. There is no recognition that what we are dealing with here is a fundamental basic right of the Canadian people.
There is no mention in the Throne Speech of legislation respecting Indian self-government. In the last Parliament, you may recall, Mr. Speaker, the government introduced such legislation. It fell far short of what was required, but at least such legislation was introduced. Now that subject seems to have dropped right off the agenda. I would remind the Government that in the last Parliament there was an all-Party committee. It looked at the entire question of Indian self-government and concluded that the only way in which the problems of the Indian people could be met was through Indian self-government.
It recognized that there were three approaches to Indian self-government, and that all should be followed. First, there was the constitutional entrenchment, about which I have already spoken. Second, there was the bilateral approach where the federal government deals directly with the governments of Indian first nations. Third, there was the legislative approach whereby the federal government would pass enabling legislation. There is no mention of this in the Throne Speech. Unless we begin to deal with this fundamental problem that affects Indian people from one end of Canada to the other, then we are ignoring one of the basic groups within Canadian society.
The speech promised the removal of discriminatory clauses in the Indian Act. Again, this is something that we in our Party welcome, and we look forward to seeing the legislation which the Government will table. This longstanding problem has to be solved. I hope that this Government does not do as the last government did, which was to wait until the last possible moment and then to try to jam through unsatisfactory legislation without giving the committee adequate time for discussion and without giving the Indian people most affected adequate time to make their presentation.
I hope that as the Government deals with discrimination in the Indian Act it will pay attention to what the Indian people say, both to the national Indian organizations and also to the Native Women's Association of Canada.
This past spring the Native Women's Association of Canada and the Assembly of First Nations have reached a certain consensus about how this problem should be approached and addressed. The previous government chose to ignore that consensus. I hope that the present Government is a little more sensitive.

speechtext:
While the Government talks about developing consensus in some areas, in other areas it is prepared to move ahead on its own without consultation and without consensus. Here, of course, I am talking about cut-backs and increases in taxes which, in effect, are taking money out of our communities and taking money out of circulation, which will have a depressing effect on the economy.
I want to point out that these cut-backs by and large have been motivated by ideology rather than by any clear plan. This was revealed last week on November 13 when the Hon. Member for Winnipeg North Centre (Mr. Keeper) asked the Minister of State for Science and Technology (Mr. Siddon) about cutting the Manufacturing Technology Institute in Winnipeg. When he asked what studies had been done, the Minister replied that there had been no studies of the impact and that the real issue was one of political philosophy. We would like to see political philosophy at least brought into some context with reality.
It is interesting that the book of the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) entitled A New Direction for Canada talked about the needs of small businesses. In part it reads:
Keeping public sector research activities in tune with small firm needs, and the broader issue of rapid technology diffusion in the small business sector, are important subjects for discussion. We must examine the role of government-financed technology centres, and the possibility of industry-wide private-public sector research efforts.
There was no examination of the role of the centre in Winnipeg. It was simply cut.
Studies of the impact of these cuts were conducted for Cabinet. We want to see what those studies indicated in detail. We know they predicted that there would be job loss, but we do not know how much. The Minister of Finance said that it was "statistically insignificant". We would like to see those studies. We would like Canadians to see them so that they could judge for themselves whether or not they were statistically insignificant. We do not believe that they are insignificant, and we challenge the Government to release the studies and let Canadians decide. Last week Informetrica Limited indicated that, as a result of the Government's cut-backs,
50,000	jobs would be lost.
Some cuts primarily concern me. First I refer to the $200 million cut in the unemployment insurance fund through a series of what is euphemistically referred to as intensified interviews. This is a nice sounding phrase, but in practice it means that unemployed people, people on unemployment insurance, will be hassled and hounded from their entitlement by more regulations. Is this part of the Government's new consensus toward which it is working in terms of who will share the benefits and who will share the burdens? It seems to me the result is that the victims of unemployment will be sharing even more of the burden of unemployment.
There is also a cut of $175 million from the Industrial and Regional Development Program. Most of this comes from tier
November 19, 1984

1 communities. They will no longer be eligible for any assistance for establishing, expanding or modernizing manufacturing facilities. In British Columbia where there is the third highest unemployment rate in Canada, there is only one community designated as tier 3. Half of them are in tier 2 and the other half are in tier 1. We are not receiving our fair share of benefits under the program as it is presently constituted. By cutting back on the benefits available to tier 1, we will be discriminated against in doubly.
Then there is a $7.8 million cut-back from Indian Affairs, $5 million of which comes from capital funds. These funds are needed to help build schools and sewers. Over the last four years our committee looked at this, and representatives from all parties recognized the urgent need of Indian communities for infrastructure, sewers and water systems. We heard representation from one community after another about the need for new school buildings and how we were falling behind in that regard, yet the Government is cutting $5 million from capital funds.
The Government is cutting $400,000 from special needs for Indian communities like emergency assistance for communities after fires. The Government is cutting $350,000 from cultural grants that would go to Indian artists in order to sponsor Indian art displays. It is interesting to note that the Throne Speech merely gives lip service to art. Reading from page 7 of Hansard, the Throne Speech indicates:
As a country rich in human resources, Canada owes much to those who have dedicated themselves to cultural, artistic and athletic endeavour. In a variety of areas, my Government will be addressing itself to the challenge of encouraging those individuals who inspire Canadians to new levels of excellence.
What kind of encouragement is being given to Indian artists when there are these kinds of cut-backs to the funding of Indian art?
Over the last few years, Indian art has been a great expression of the Indian people and has helped them to move toward their rightful place in Canadian society. Art has helped Indians gain a new sense of their own dignity and their own place in the scheme of things. As well, Indian art has given non-Indians a better understanding of Indians. The same is true of Inuit art. We are now cutting back funding that would help further those endeavours. As well, we have seen cut-backs to the funding of other cultural agencies.
The Speech from the Throne does not address some of the vital areas of concern in our economy. Government members have pointed out that the Speech from the Throne is not meant to be a shopping list. That is fair enough. We are not looking for a shopping list. However, I would like to ask government members if forestry is simply one item on a shopping list. We have heard of a great deal of concern about the growing deficit in the financial situation. I would like to ask government members about the growing deficit in timber supply. The Government recognized this deficit during the election campaign and promised immediate action. Where is that action now? Where are the plans to create a full-fledged Forestry
The Address-Mr. Manly
Department with its own full Minister? It is not enough for forestry to be a poor cousin of agriculture.
We want to ask, where are the new programs for job creation? Where are the tens of thousands of jobs that were to be created as soon as this new Government was sworn into office?
In conclusion, I would simply like to urge government members to look to the Province of British Columbia with the hope that perhaps they can see the British Columbia experience as being a bad example. My father has said that even the worst of us can serve as a bad example. That is what has occurred in British Columbia today. In July, 1983, the British Columbia Government introduced a program of restraints and cut-backs emphasizing that these cut-backs were not introduced simply for the sake of cutting back but were introduced for the sake of recovery. Yet, since that program has been instituted, the economy has gone downhill. Investor confidence has gone down and unemployment has gone up. Now the deficit is rising.
It has been said by Santayana, I believe, that whoever will not learn from history is destined to repeat it. I hope that the Government is prepared to learn from the history of British Columbia so that all the people of Canada will not be condemned to repeat the tragic history of British Columbia, which has wasted its resources and, in the last year and a half, lost any possibility of recovery. The Government of British Columbia is now beginning to reconsider its approach. I urge the Government of Canada to reconsider its approach and, rather than bringing in cut-backs, bring in a positive program that will create jobs and ensure that the poor people of Canada receive the benefits and not only the burdens of technological change.

Member, I would like to point out that at the present time British Columbia is not getting its fair share with the way the tier system is set up. Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the Hon. Member for his question. I believe that as the consensus
between the Native Women's Association and the Assembly of First Nations developed last year, the approach was that the federal Government would have the responsibility for granting Indian status in terms of a general list. People would be eligible for federal Government assistance, but the access to actual membership within Indian bands would be the result of action taken by those bands themselves. I would support that position provided it is in accordance with non-discriminatory rules, so that what is acceptable to men is acceptable to women as well.
Yes, I believe that Indian first nations do have to have some control over their band membership. However, I also believe that the federal Government has a basic responsibility to make funding available to Indian first nations so that they can receive women and their children back into band membership without an increased financial burden.
I hope that when the federal Government introduces this legislation with respect to removing this discrimination, it will not forget that we have an obligation to make funding available so that the entire burden of the change is not put upon the Indian people themselves. It has been said very well that we should not put a dollar tag on justice. That applies to the Indian people as well, that they not hold Indian women up for ransom while waiting until the federal Government pays the appropriate amount of money. They are beginning to recognize that and have moved a long way in that respect, as I am sure the Hon. Member will recognize.
The opposite side of that coin, however, is that we in this House, the federal Government, should not put a dollar tag on justice. We should do everything we can to make sure that the financial resources are available to Indian communities so that they can receive women back into membership without adding to the burden of poverty which, as the Hon. Member knows, is already widespread in most Indian communities.

I would also like to say that I was most impressed by the remark of the mover and seconder in reply to the Speech from the Throne. They are two very different people who happen to sit together in the House of Commons. One Hon. Member is from Montreal, and the other Hon. Member is from Sarnia. Sarnia reflects so well what is possible for Canada from a resource development point of view, and Montreal-Mercier is, in many ways, the end product of that. 1 happen to be very interested in harness racing and I used to go to Richelieu Raceway. 1 had to pass through the constituency of that young lady of 23 years of age. 1 know that the people of Montreal-Mercier are going to be well served by that Hon. Member in the days ahead.
I happen to have a very outstanding constituent in my riding. Sometimes she lives in my constituency and sometimes
The Address-Mr. Coates
she does not. She originally came from Springhill. Her name is Anne Murray. She has a very nice cottage compound in the Pugwash area of my constituency and she comes and visits with us. She won an award recently for a song about good news and bad news. Well, Sir, I do not know how anyone else feels on Monday morning, but I could hardly believe the news this morning. As a matter of fact, I could hardly believe the news I have heard over the last few days. First, we have a former Prime Minister, who, when he presided over the Liberal Party, watched it being decimated in the provinces until it reached a point where it did not hold a provincial government anywhere in this country. Second, he turned the Party over to another leader at the eleventh hour and watched him lead the Party to another degree of decimation which is hard to comprehend. We then hear that former Prime Minister announce that maybe if he had continued on as the leader of the Liberal Party, it would have won the election. On top of that, the present critic for external affairs is saying that it is too bad the Liberal Party did not select him. Well, he had every opportunity to be selected. He went to a leadership convention where it was decided that the present Leader was preferable. Then that critic goes on, in the footsteps of the Right Hon. Pierre Trudeau, and says, "If I had been selected, things would have been a lot better for the Liberal Party". All I can say is that with friends like those the Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition has in the Liberal Party, he does not need any enemies.
If that is not bad enough, this outstanding internationalist, who set his Party up for almost total destruction, is telling the present Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney), who led the Progressive Conservative Party to the greatest victory in the history of this nation with the first national government since 1963 at least, that he had better watch the way he is operating. Well, I think I would prefer to have him advising his former Party than advising us, thank you very much.
We have difficult days ahead, Mr. Speaker. In a very courageous statement, the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) told Canadians how it really is. There is no smoke and there are no mirrors. It is the real thing, and the Canadian people know it. That is why the Liberal Party sits in the House of Commons with over 100 seats less than they had in 1980. Through total fiscal and monetary irresponsibility, they have led this country into the mess we are in at the moment.
The previous speaker said that we are not talking about jobs. Everything we do at this moment in time is geared to jobs because, unless we get deficit reduction in place, there will be no jobs. All of the money that we take from the taxpayers will go to pay interest on monies borrowed in an attempt to maintain the deficit as it increases from the present $180 billion, to something like $400 billion owing. There is nothing we can do until we get that deficit under control. Working together, the Minister of Finance and the President of the Treasury Board (Mr. de Cotret) have given the signal to Canadians that we are going to put our financial house in order. Flowing from that will be the real, long-term jobs that

November 19, 1984
The Address-Mr. Coates
Canadians aspire to and desire. We are going to ensure that they get them.
The President of the Treasury Board announced a reduction of $154 million in the defence budget. The Liberal Party felt that that was calamitous. The only useful thing that the Liberal Government did from an economic point of view was to reduce the rate of inflation in the country. As a result of that decrease in the rate of inflation and of more realistic purchases by officials in the National Defence Department, a saving of $154 million was effected without interfering in any way with present or future commitments which we have made. Therefore, the Canadian people need not be concerned about the $154 million deficit reduction which was announced by the President of the Treasury Board.
The Speech from the Throne refers to a comprehensive examination of the role of the defence forces in the strategic context of the 1980s. I am happy to say that examination is already under way. I shall be devoting a good deal of my time, as will officials of my Department, to doing what is necessary to ensure that the examination is thorough and that the result is unambiguous. I intend to ask for the co-operation of my colleagues and to draw on the resources of their Departments in this enterprise. That is not all. I shall also be seeking the expert advice and good counsel of individuals and organizations across the country in the pursuit of our objectives. The objective is clear, namely, to clarify the mandate of our military and to give them the resources they need to do their job.
Perhaps, Mr. Speaker, it would be helpful if I were to say a few words about our point of departure in this examination. There may also be some interest in the sort of question which we will be addressing in the preparation of a paper which I would propose to table for discussion early next year, and which the Government will be answering, following discussion, in a white paper on defence.
One thing that I want to make absolutely clear is that the Government will not be approaching this examination as a means of determining how to do less for the collective defence. There is an unfortunate impression abroad that when a government reviews its position on defence, it is seeking ways to do less. That is not the Government's intention. That is not our way. Rather, we intend to determine how best to ensure that Canada does its fair share to preserve peace in freedom. Our aim is to ensure that Canada's Armed Forces are charged with doing what they can do to the greatest effect in the common defence. Our objective for the forces themselves is to ensure that they are then able to do what we ask of them.
On a number of occasions I have had meetings with the Hon. Member for Northumberland-Miramichi (Mr. Jardine). I have had discussions with his Premier and with my officials. We are moving forward to eliminate the problem which exists at this moment in time with regard to Chatham. The Prime Minister made certain commitments prior to and during the election campaign with regard to Chatham. It is my intention to carry through on those commitments.
We should all be proud of the positive role played by our forces in the development of our great nation. We should be proud too of what they are attempting to do to help perserve the way of life that we share with our allies on both sides of the Atlantic.
In the course of the past month I have met with NATO Defence Ministers collectively and individually. In Washington I met with Defense Secretary Weinberger and in London 1 met with Defense Secretary Heseltine. 1 received the warmest tributes to the high standards of the Canadian Armed Forces. In all of my meetings with these and other Defence Ministers I affirmed the intention of the Government to maintain those standards, to continue real growth in Canada's defence expenditures, and to give the highest possible priority to increasing the effectiveness of the Canadian Armed Forces in carrying out our commitments within the alliance.
It is against this background of solidarity with our allies and determination to enlarge and improve our co-operation that we shall be conducting the examination of our situation. It is in the light of the need to strengthen our arms in the defence of our values and to strengthen our voice in allied councils that we will be planning for the future. The responsiveness of Canada's defence industrial base in accommodating the production needs of the Canadian forces and those of our allies in times of peace and emergency is a key element of national and collective security.
Interdependence in defence implies and requires interdependence in the economic basis of defence. Therefore, we will want to satisfy ourselves as to the vitality of our partnership with others in bilateral and multilateral defence research, development and production agreements and arrangements.
Beginning on December 3, a briefing team from the Department of Defense in the United States will be travelling across Canada to assist all those who are associated with defence procurement in Canada in finding ways in which they can participate to a greater degree than at the present time in the acquiring of contracts, either prime contracts or subcontracts, with the United States defense establishment firms. That will be of real benefit, not only to our defence industry in Canada, but to our over-all co-operation with the United States.
This is an example of the concrete proposals that flow from the type of meeting that were held with the Prime Minister of Canada and the President of the United States. It is what is called the bread and butter which stems from that type of meeting. It involves the actual jobs that people are talking about which could flow to the various companies in Canada through new defence procurement contracts. It is an indication of our commitment to what we have been proposing.

in Saskatoon; and December 14, at the downtown Eloliday Inn in Winnipeg.
These meetings to be held across Canada will give all those in the business who are interested in defence procurement an opportunity to understand fully how they can obtain contracts from the United States to make jobs for Canadian in Canada as part of the over-all commitment between Canada and the United States in the field of defence.
However, we must always remember that industrial capacity and economic strength are only partial and imperfect indicators of our ability to serve the cause of peace and security. Our military worth as a partner and ally in the great enterprise to deter aggression and pursue the goal of arms limitations and control is measured in terms of the strength and effectiveness of our Armed Forces. The strength of our Armed Forces is measured in the men and women who can be deployed and in the quality and quantity of the equipment and supplies they have at any given time for their use.
1 worry that in the event of hostilities the Canadian Armed Forces might not be sufficiently manned and equipped to carry out the tasks expected of them. Modern warfare-more particularly the deterrents of actions leading to such warfare- demands well trained personnel and reliable, up to date equipment.
The United States strategic defence initiative will also attract our interest. As Hon. Members know, in March of last year, President Reagan unveiled an initiative which, if successful, would fundamentally change the strategic relationship from one of assured destruction to one of defence assisted assured survival. President Reagan called for people, not weapons, to be protected: weapons, not people, were to be threatened.
Dr. Ikle, the American Under-Secretary of Defense for policy, came to Ottawa two weeks ago to discuss strategic defence with me and officials from my Department. It is in the sense that the United States is attempting to remove the nuclear sword of Damocles which hangs over all our heads that this effort should be viewed. In all of its ramifications, it is a program of immense interest to my Department, and to Canada, and it is one which we shall want to follow closely in the years ahead.
The Government is determined to meet its responsibilities to the men and women in the Canadian Armed Forces by providing them with the tools they need to carry out their commitments. Mr. Speaker, I suppose most mistresses are always annoyed with the position they hold in society. They would rather be the wife, but a mistress they are and a mistress they shall remain, I am afraid.
I would like to set forth my own view. Perhaps it will offer some advice to new Members. I know they are working hard and will continue to do so. During all that hard work, they should continue to see government as a whole. They should sit in the House and learn its fascinating life. More than anything, the Throne Speech set forth that this was a time of reconciliation and reconstruction across the country. In order to achieve this, new Members would be well advised to spend a lot of time travelling, to use those very generous tickets which taxpayers provide. They should go to Newfoundland to get to know the people; they should go out to British Columbia to get to know the people. When they have done so, they will have seen the regions which send colleagues and other Members to the House. I assure them that their love for the country and Canadian people will grow immensely after having seen people in their own environments. Then they will understand what they say.
They will appreciate more and more that when a Member from Newfoundland stands, he or she speaks from the unique and dynamic cultural background which the people of Newfoundland have developed over hundreds of years. Likewise for us from the Prairies because, while we may be only the third generation, there was a great experiment on the Prairies when people came from many countries throughout the world. We were thrown together with different languages and different cultures. Initially we tried to protect our languages and cultures. When faced with a prairie winter, when it was 40 below and the wind was blowing the colour of eyes of your neighbour, their skin or the language they spoke did not
November 19, 1984

matter. We were locked into a battle against the elements. As a result, we were pulled together into a communal effort. Sons and daughters then naturally fell in love with each other and, as a result, the country was immensely enhanced.
The real advantage of travel is that one can no longer depersonalize the people of another region. When Hon. Members like myself travel home, they hear from a small part of their ridings, that 1 per cent or 2 per cent we call the bigots. It makes us shudder when we realize the extent to which they depersonalize people in other parts of the country. I think Hon. Members will find that their biggest job will be to speak out against the local myths and against that very small part of the population that we call bigots. I find even in my own riding that I am forever attending meetings at which I have to stand up and say: "No, I am sorry, you are simply wrong, my friend. Your view of the people of Ontario is wrong, your view of the people of Newfoundland is wrong". It is important for new Members to have the courage to be able to stand up to their own people and point out that they are wrong. They should have the courage to say: "I have been in other parts of the country. I know the people from Quebec and I know the people from Newfoundland. They are not as you describe them". Members will soon find that they will spend quite a bit of their time doing that.
The Throne Speech is the first of three new major changes in this country. It certainly sets a tone of civility and a tone of national reconstruction both economically and politically. That element of co-operation between the governments will pay off in the long run. The hard truth of the matter is that over the last 15 years, while we as a people and as elected Members have spent so much of our emotional energy and vitality fighting each other, whether it be federal-provincial, Francophone-Anglophone or East-West fights, the rest of the world has been passing us by. When we look now with fresh eyes at the international scene, we find that Asia is coming on strong with its high technology. If we do not get onstream, Mr. Speaker, we will be left behind for many, many years. Our children and grandchildren will not have the future we would want them to have.
The second major change forecast by the Throne Speech was the economic statement. I would like to begin my discussion of that statement by thanking the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) because, for the first time, this country has been faced with an economic statement that is truly honest, truly frank and has the courage to ask the tough questions. The difference between a successful country and an unsuccessful country is that the successful country will face reality. For 15 years, we have been trying to deny the reality of the developing Third World. Third World countries have large populations and their literacy level is rising. These countries want to participate in world affairs and they will participate in world affairs. The previous government simply denied that fact and, as a result, Canadians are now paying the price.
The Address-Mr. Thacker
A classic example of this relates to the energy policy. When the OPEC nations put up the price of energy, different countries reacted in different ways. The Liberal regime that was running this country denied that reality and indicated that it would take taxpayers' dollars and continue to subsidize energy so that Canadians would not have to face reality. That indication sent signals to Canadians to continue to buy big cars and to the automobile manufacturing industry to continue to produce big cars. Initially, the same thing happened in the United States. Meanwhile, Japan, Germany and the other countries that followed that price increase turned their best brains to designing new cars that were more efficient and lighter. Eight years later, those countries are selling cars here in Canada and our automobile industry is on the ropes. Finally, we had to face the reality. Energy prices began to rise. Our scientists are just as bright as the scientists in those other countries, and our inventive genius is just as bright as the inventive genius in those other countries. Now North American cars are beginning to compete and will compete more and more.
The basic point I am trying to make is that the Government tried to deny the reality of the world. As a result, Canadians are worse off today. We are having to struggle from behind rather than being a leader. Another example of this deals with research and particularly with research in the agricultural sector. This country was once a world pacesetter and leader in developing new varieties and species of crops. As a result, we became an enormous exporter of those crops. During the last 15 years, however, under the Liberal regime, that research and development has dropped behind. How do we get caught up? We would like to have a plant breeders' rights statute implemented so that people can develop new varieties of crops again. Some Parties and church groups are opposed to the introduction of that statute. This is simply a way of condemning the country to being always behind in research and development. The Government has not put enough money into research and development and will not put enough money into research and development because it is in debt for so many other reasons.
The Minister of Finance performed a truly valuable service to this country. The next period of consultation between the federal and provincial governments and between business and labour will culminate next April in a real budget speech. At that time, the true direction of this country will be set and we will return to creating genuine wealth.
There is no doubt that the primary issue to be dealt with at this moment is the national debt and the deficit. If any of us need any further proof of that, we simply need to look at the statistics of a mere 10 years ago. In 1974-75, 16.6 per cent of our GNP was taken up by the net debt. A mere 10 years later, in 1984-85, that percentage rose from 16.6 per cent to 45.2 per cent of the GNP being taken up by the net debt. That tells us, Mr. Speaker, that the percentage is rising at a geometric rate.
Soon we will be no better off than the Third World countries, because the percentage of the tax revenue that goes to service the debt is the real bottom line issue. What is happening is that more and more of the results of the sweat and toil of our people is being taken off right at the top in order to pay

November 19, 1984
The Address-Mr. Thacker
interest on the debt. This money is being paid to people who already have wealth. The point is, Mr. Speaker, that if you had $1 million, there is no way you would invest it in a plant or business in this country, because you could sit back, lend it to the Government and receive an absolutely guaranteed rate of return with no risk. The rich are becoming fabulously rich.
When looking at the history of Third World countries, we find that often they went through the same process. All of the wealth was being concentrated into very few hands. There was a small group of people with immense wealth and a huge lower class with no wealth at all. That is what is happening in this country, and we must stop that.
I am always struck by the irony of comparing the New Democratic Party with the Progressive Conservative Party. I suspect that proportionately, more people of wealth belong to the PC Party than the NDP. Yet it is members of the PC Party who are saying that this concentration of wealth is wrong. They are saying that we must stop that deficit so that the rich, many of whom are members of the PC Party, cannot continue to become filthy rich. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to begin by congratualting you on your appointment as Acting Speaker of the House of Commons. I have been most impressed with your firm deliberations and sense of fairness during the first two weeks of this Parliament. Hon. Members from both sides of this House have cause to be proud of their new Speaker. I wish you every success in discharging your new responsibilities.
May I also take this opportunity to congratulate the "Class of '84", my newly elected fellow Members of Parliament. As has been said, "Blessed are the meek for they shall inherit the earth". My congratulations as well to all of the re-elected Members of the House of Commons.
Before I begin my remarks, I would like to extend my sincerest appreciation to the residents of York South-Weston for their expression of faith in my candidacy and for placing their trust and confidence in me on September 4. I am proud and honoured to be their Member of Parliament. I give to my constituents, Mr. Speaker, my solemn pledge that I will faithfully discharge my responsibilities with integrity, honesty and thoughtfulness. I will devote my full and complete energies to the task of working not only for the best interests of my constituents but for the best interests of Canadians from coast to coast. It has often been said that a Canadian can enjoy no higher honour than to be selected by his fellow citizens to represent them in this House of Commons. I wholeheartedly believe this to be true.
I feel a very special debt of gratitude to all of those who have devoted their time and energy and who have worked so very hard on my election campaign. I am here because of them and I shall always remember and cherish their generosity and friendship. Please permit me as well, Mr. Speaker, to thank
some very special people in my life, my family, especially my parents and sisters and brothers, for all their devotion, love and hard work.
I would also like to acknowledge my predecessor, the former Member of Parliament for York South-Weston, Mrs. Ursula Appolloni, who served the riding with distinction for ten years. Her work in Parliament reflected her deep commitment to our country. Many Hon. Members of this House will recall that York South-Weston was represented previous to Mrs. Appolloni by the former Leader of the New Democratic Party, the late David Lewis. There is little I can add to what has been said many times about Mr. Lewis's great contribution to Canada and to Parliament. Suffice it to say that I am honoured to continue the work of two distinguished and dedicated parliamentarians.
I understand it is traditional, Mr. Speaker, for a new Member of Parliament to describe the riding he or she represents for the benefit of Hon. Members. The riding of York South-Weston is an urban riding in the west part of Metropolitan Toronto. It can be described as a multicultural working class riding. The proportion of people who describe their country of origin as being other than British or French comprises 53 per cent of the population of York South-Weston. There is a significant Italian community in my riding of which I am a proud member. In fact, 11,000 of my constituents list Italian as their mother tongue. I might add at this point, Mr. Speaker, that the Canadian-Italian community is honoured to have elected to Parliament six Italian Canadians-five Liberals and a Conservative-the most ever in Canadian political history.
There are many nationalities from every corner of the globe in York South-Weston, including people from Europe, the Middle East, Asia and the sub-continent. There is as well a high proportion of new Canadians. Between 1965 and 1978 some 20,000 individuals from other countries decided to make their home within the boundaries of my riding. These new Canadians work side by side with the native born in companies such as Cooper Sports Equipment, Levy Brothers Machinery, Kodak of Canada, Canada Packers and Pepsi-Cola, to name just a few. Although there are cultural, linguistic and racial differences, both new and old Canadians regard Canada as the land of opportunity. Through their hard work and sacrifice they are determined to build a better life for themselves and their families.
My parents immigrated to Canada in the early 1950s and settled in Revelstoke, British Columbia, which happens to be my home town. For them, indeed, Canada was the land of opportunity. They worked hard, they sacrificed and they built a better life for themselves and for their seven children. Canada gave them the opportunity as it gave it to many other immigrants.
There are also many senior citizens in York South-Weston, people who have made this country what it is today. In our deliberations we must never forget the observation of historian Arnold Toynbee that a society's quality and durability can best be measured "by the respect and care given its elderly citi-
November 19, 1984

zens". One of the most ennobling duties of government is to ensure that the elderly are accorded the dignity and security they so richly deserve.
As one of the youngest Members of this House, I am a product of the 1960s and 1970s, an era which saw incredible upheaval and change: Vietnam, the "hippie movement', student demonstrations, Watergate, and political assassinations. It was also an era which witnessed a strong undercurrent of idealism. The Kennedys and Martin Luther King challenged humanity with a vision of decency and brotherhood which we have yet to realize. Their dreams must never die and our efforts for a better world must never cease. As John Kennedy said, "We are not here to curse the darkness but to light the candle that can guide us through the darkness to a safe and sane future".
Kennedy once described himself as an idealist without illusions. As part of a new generation of Liberals, I share these sentiments. Liberals understand the power of idealism and that government can and must be used as an instrument for moral progress. Government must be fair and compassionate. It must be quick to respond to the needy in society. It must be the protectorate of our democratic institutions and the advocate of individual rights and freedoms. Caring for the disadvantaged in our society, the sick, the disabled, the poor, the unemployed, the elderly, increasing opportunities for women and our young people and sharing with the less fortunate in our society is the Liberal legacy. This is the tradition of Canadian liberalism, a tradition fostered by Laurier and continued by King, St. Laurent, Pearson, Trudeau and now Turner. It has been this leadership, during this century, that has guided Canada to its place as one of the most humane and decent societies anywhere in the world.
But, Mr. Speaker, Liberals are also realists. We are pragmatists. We are without illusions as to what can and cannot be done by government. We understand that it is the individual who, through initiatives and sacrifice, is the source of our economic strength and the engine of growth. We, as Liberals, fight to correct abuses and injustices within our society. Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere. We in the Liberal Party, now Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition, intend to live by this philosophy over the course of the Thirty-third Parliament because we are the Party of reform.
The Speech from the Throne that began this Parliament is certainly a most important document. As Hon. Members opposite know only too well, a Conservative Government in this country is a rare bird indeed and one that seldom, if ever, learns to fly. Conservative Throne speeches, as a result, are such rare documents that Canadians had a right to expect much more from this one. Traditionally the Speech from the Throne affords a Government the opportunity to translate its election promises into a blueprint for legislative action.
If the recent Throne Speech is any indication, however, that tradition has suffered a serious setback. The Throne Speech repeated some of the Conservative election promises. It also
The Address-Mr. Nunziata
spoke of re-introducing many important Liberal initiatives from the last Parliament. However, it did not reveal any substantive description of how the Government intends to follow through on its campaign commitments.
I concede the fact that Throne Speeches are, by their very nature, general. But this document is so vague and contains so few specifics, that it truly lacks any substance or depth. Indeed, Mr. Speaker, it gives Canadians a very poor reference point from which to judge Tory promises against Tory action. Tory action to date is diametrically opposed to Tory election promises. The Tories made many promises during the election campaign, a number of which were irresponsible, in my view.
There were to be tens of thousands of jobs just as soon as a new government was sworn in. Where are they? We are still waiting. There was to be an open and accessible government. Where is it? It is nowhere to be found. They promised hope to our young people. Instead, they exacerbated the despair and snuffed any light of hope that existed. The list of broken promises goes on and on.
It will soon become abundantly clear as the honeymoon fades that the Tories have hoodwinked the Canadian electorate. Canadians have been seriously jilted by the Conservative Party, and I would submit, Mr. Speaker, with fraudulent intent. In their thirst for power the Tories were either innocently naive or deliberately dishonest with Canadians. Is it any wonder, Mr. Speaker, that the integrity of politicians is so often called into question?
The Throne Speech is virtually silent on how the Government actually intends to pursue solutions to Canada's problems. We are promised consultations, studies, task forces, talk and more talk, when what we need is action.
It is obvious from the Throne Speech that the Tories really do not know what they are doing. They really do not know what to do about our greatest problem, namely unemployment. Astonishingly, one of their first acts as a government was an economic statement that will have the effect of increasing, not decreasing, the unemployment roles. The Government must address the tragedy of unemployment and must do so quickly. The unemployed cannot wait for the off chance that the private sector will create much-needed jobs.
The Conservatives have put their blind faith in the free enterprise system and in the private sector creating jobs. Let us not forget that business is in business to create profit, not jobs. A corporation has no moral conscience to create jobs. It has no obligation to our unemployed. But government must and does have an obligation toward those who want to work but cannot.
Government is in business for people. We are not running a railroad. Government is not judged by its balance sheet, but rather by the way it treats its people, by the way it cares, and by its sense of justice. The Tory paranoia and pre-occupation with the deficit will only serve to create more serious hardships for those who have already suffered and for those who are less able to care for themselves. I agree, Mr. Speaker, that the Government must be fiscally responsible, but let it not be

morally irresponsible. Let us manage the deficit; let us not have the deficit manage us.
The question of unemployment and what the Government has done so far leads naturally into a further discussion of broken promises. One promise that tops the broken promises list and goes right to the heart of the new Government's credibility is the promise of open government. The Tory election campaign handbook says, "We will run an open, honest and accountable national Government". It adds that a new Tory Government would be "open to public scrutiny". The handbook says that Liberals have denied Canadians legitimate access to Government. It says that the Liberal Party has refused to release Government information, and it reports that Liberals have restricted access to Government records despite freedom of information legislation.
This Parliament is not yet three weeks old and already the Secretary of State for External Affairs (Mr. Clark) has publicly repudiated directions he had issued for open government when he was Prime Minister. A severe and totally unwarranted muzzle has been placed on public servants in their dealings with the press. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. Nielsen) has warned colleagues that if they talk to journalists, their jobs could be in danger. Ministers' staffs are not responding to legitimate questions from reporters. There have been thwarted moves to suppress news releases from private organizations. If this is the "New Ottawa", I will take the old one any day. Parliament is truly becoming Orwell's Animal Farm under the Conservative Government.
Let us look at some of the other promises. During the election campaign the Prime Minister constantly praised Liberal social programs and medicare, calling them "a sacred trust" and pledging never to tamper with the concept of universality. Within days of this Parliament's opening, the backtracking started. Now he says all programs are under review.
The deficit is another case in point. During the election campaign, in August as a matter of fact, the Prime Minister said that the deficit was not an overriding priority. Because of the need to create jobs quickly, he could envision some increase in the deficit. Then he reversed himself in the Throne Speech by saying that an immediate and substantial cut would have to be made in the deficit in order to produce jobs. Now he is saying, based on a speech given in Toronto last week, that even if the deficit is cut, unemployment will remain high.
The question of broken promises is an important one, especially concerning the economy, but an even more important question was raised by an economic analyst in a recent column when he asked, "Does the Mulroney Government really know what it is doing?" I will leave that judgment to the Canadian public, Mr. Speaker.
Let us look at some of the other promises. In October the Secretary of State for External Affairs, repeating a campaign pledge, said at the United Nations that our Government intends to maintain Canada's commitment to reach by 1990 7 per cent of the Gross National Product in official development assistance. Several weeks thereafter, the Minister of Finance

In Pocket Politics, their campaign bible, the Tories said, "We believe that all levels of government and the private sector face a major task in resolving the tragic youth unemployment situation".

subsubtopic: CANCELLATION OF NORTH YORK TAX CENTRE PROJECT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the Government's great urge to cut, cut, cut, it has once again forgotten about people needs and people concerns.
Just recently the Government announced the cancellation of a $58 million tax centre to be built in the city of North York. Government representatives were quoted as saying that it was part of a move to trim the construction budget. Well, it appeared that they used a machete to do their trimming.
This unfortunate trim means that the City of North York will lose $1 million in tax revenues. It will mean a loss of 3,000 jobs, 1,000 full-time and 2,000 part-time. It will also mean a loss of hundreds upon hundreds of jobs that would have been created in the construction sector. It means the loss for North York citizens of the many services that were to be theirs. The City had approved the rezoning of the 20-acre, 42,000 square foot complex. Everything was in place. However, in one fell swoop we lost jobs, services, and civic pride.
This is the sad reflection of an insensitive, unilateral, job losing cut-back that looks only at statistics rather than to the people behind those statistics.
I therefore ask the Minister of National Revenue (Mr. Beatty) to reverse this unfortunate decision and give credibility to the expectations that he created for the Department of Revenue when he was in opposition.

subsubtopic: CALL FOR FREE VOTE ON RESTORATION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in light of yet another police killing in Ontario last week, how long can we as legislators ignore this horror? Constable Miller's funeral is probably being held this very minute in Mathe-son, Ontario.
Are we behind our law enforcement officers, or not? Parliamentary waffling on this issue is a vote of non confidence for Canadian policemen. They spend every waking hour protecting us, yet we refuse to reciprocate.
Murder statistics in this country would be much higher were it not for great advances in medicine over recent years. In order to get a true picture of the occurrence of such crimes we must look closely at attempted murder statistics as well.
I am aware that there are two private Members' Bills in the works which advocate capital punishment. Instead, the Government should introduce a Bill allowing a free vote in the near future. This matter is far too important to put on the backburner.
I believe calling for a vote is a direct reflection of the public sentiment which is, after all, our mandate. Any confidence that we can give our policemen should be granted immediately. If the reconstitution of capital punishment saves the life of
just one policeman, we shall have fulfilled our duties as elected officials. We must end this political delinquence now.

subsubtopic: CANADIAN WILDLIFE SERVICE-EFFECT OF BUDGETARY CUT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, among those affected by the cuts announced by the Government are 84 people who will lose their jobs in the Canadian Wildlife Service, which employs 384 across the nation. This means a cut of almost 25 per cent. They are highly trained biologists, technicians, and office workers.
If these jobs are terminated next spring, urgent work on the environment will be abandoned. The affected projects include the study of toxics in the Great Lakes, the tracing of toxic contamination in gull eggs, the tracing of many forms of toxic contamination in wildlife habitat, the management of endangered species, the tracking of the movement of wildlife by way of radio collars, the effects of budworm spray on wildlife and songbirds, and many other projects. Does the Government expect these people to find employment within provincial government wildlife services and, if not, does it expect them to find employment abroad?

subsubtopic: FIVE-YEAR FOOTWEAR IMPORT RESTRAINT PROGRAM ADVOCATED
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, for some time the Canadian footwear industry has been consistently seeking a comprehensive and effective period of import relief to allow it the time to invest in new emerging technologies. Consequently, reliable restraints on footwear imports will be needed for a full five-year period if the Canadian industry is to survive as a productive and efficient industry fulfilling its potential to maintain Canadian jobs.
The restraint programs since 1980 have all been for short periods, and very spasmodic. For example, there has been a temporary termination of the leather footwear quota for one year, followed by its restoration for two and one-half years, and now a 16-month extension. These periods have seriously impeded the progress of the footwear manufacturing industry when viewed in the context of the investment process.
The industry is looking for something that is tangible and concrete-a period of reliable footwear import restraint. Therefore I call upon the Government to address itself to this serious problem, and make a positive decision which would significantly help safeguard the thousands of jobs in the Canadian footwear industry which are now in danger of being lost.

subsubtopic: UNIVERSALITY-POSITIONS OF LIBERAL AND PROGRESSIVE CONSERVATIVE PARTIES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it should come as no surprise that Liberal Leader John Turner is flip-flopping on universality. In an interview on CTV's Question Period he stated: "The Liberal Party could rethink its commitment to universal social programs". subsubtopic: PLIGHT OF THE OLDER UNEMPLOYED
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on a matter of grave concern to the people of Canada. Last Friday I was in my constituency office in Scarborough Centre and I met a gentleman aged 51, who recently lost his job. He told me of the anguish and frustration that he and his family are going through. He told me of his mortagage payments and his son's university tuition that he can no longer pay. He told me of his long, lost days searching for work, only to be turned away because of his age.
This gentleman is one of 138,000 unemployed Canadians between the ages of 45 and 55. I urge the Government to take action on this segment of the unemployed. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as 1 indicated before the luncheon adjournment, during the election campaign the Tories cried crocodile tears for the unemployed youth of this country. In Pocket Politics, their campaign bible, the Conservatives said, "We believe that all levels of Government and the private sector face a major task in resolving the tragic youth unemployment situation". But what does that Party do when it resumes power, Mr. Speaker? It cuts the Canada Summer Works Program which

November 19, 1984
The Address-Mr. O'Neil
provides thousands of summer jobs to students. It cuts the young worker's exchange program. These and other program cuts will have a devastating effect on the unemployed young of our nation. Pity the young without hope for they will have nothing to inherit.
What is worse is that we are not even told of the effect of the economic statement on unemployment because of the Government's penchant for secrecy and surreptitious government. What is it afraid of and what is it hiding? I call on the Government, Mr. Speaker, to come clean with Canadians and to put its cards on the table.
We are not here to fight old battles or to settle old scores. Our duty is clear. We must forge ahead with vision and commitment to build a strong and united Canada, a just, equitable, decent and civilized society.
What will be the role of the Liberal Party in this process? As Her Majesty's Official Opposition, we intend to be vigorous, competent and constructive. We will fight hard for the individual and the disadvantaged in our society. We intend to examine thoroughly all government proposals. As my Leader has already stated, we will support legislation when support is warranted, we will amend when amendment will serve to improve, and we will oppose when opposition is necessary. We will seek to correct errors of omission and commission in legislation and, in due course, we will outline policy alternatives and new directions. Unlike the pseudo opposition to the left, we are not fettered by dogma, we do not live in the past, and we are prepared to change for a better future.
In conclusion, Mr. Speaker, I put the Government on notice that the Liberal Party is but on a short sabbatical. While in opposition, we will rejuvenate, we will rebuild, and we will regain the support and confidence of Canadians. We will earn the right to be re-elected. Let me remind Hon. Members opposite that political defeat is as transient as political success.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to begin by congratulating you on your appointment to such a prestigious post. The manner in which you have discharged your duties today confirms the wisdom of your appointment.
I also wish to congratulate the mover and seconder of the Address in reply to the Speech from the Throne. All previous speakers have spoken well. They have enlightened me about their parts of Canada. From the other speakers I have learned something about our West Coast, our Prairies, the North, and central Canada. Today I will be telling the House and other Canadians something about my riding in Atlantic Canada.
The differences among our regions have struck me, Mr. Speaker, but I have been more impressed by our common commitment to Canada and to the development of all our regions. It is a striking feature of our Confederation that we as
Canadians accept a sharing of our national wealth. We as Canadians are prepared to share our wealth with each other and to share our wealth with the world. Canada's generous aid to Ethiopia is a fine example of this commitment to the underdeveloped world.
Many national policies are possible because we share a commitment to all Canadians. Atlantic Canadians are among the recipients of these benefits. Such programs are viewed as equitable and in the interests of all Canadians. It is therefore not prudent to suggest that such economic sharing has been done at the expense of one region more than another. In our short history there has been give and take by all Canadians. As Canadians we also hold political and social equality as a high priority. Canada is truly a country which permits each Canadian the opportunity to achieve its greatest political office, that of Prime Minister.
Our Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) is of a humble but honourable background. Notwithstanding this, he has achieved the highest political office in this land. A humble beginning was no bar, geography was no bar, nor were race and religion. That is a great compliment to our society and our system of government. Yet I agree, Mr. Speaker, there is much more to be done before we can boast of total equality of opportunity.
The election of our Prime Minister with the greatest parliamentary majority in the history of the country is a tribute to him as a man. I am proud of our Prime Minister. He is providing the sound leadership Canadians have not received in decades but have so dearly wanted. In addition, Mr. Speaker, I have a special reason to be proud. Canada's eighteenth Prime Minister is a graduate of St. Francis Xavier University, a distinguished institution situated in my riding.
My constituents, Mr. Speaker, are representative of many cultures: Irish, Scottish, English, Dutch, native and Acadian, to name only some. In an effort to better represent my Acadian constituents I have begun the process of learning the French language. My next major statement to this House will be in both official languages.
We in Cape Breton Highlands-Canso are a people of basic values. We are people close to the land and the sea. The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso have a history of social service, having supported missions around the world and the training of Third World leaders on the principles of co-operatives at the Coady International Institute. We have a history of supporting our neighbours, not only next door, but across the world's oceans. Sharing is very much a value we hold.
The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso regard the family as a most valued institution. I resist the urging to describe our values as traditional. To some that reference connotes a lack of worldliness. In light of the value we place on the family, it should come as no surprise, Mr. Speaker, that the people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso value the life of unborn children. It is no surprise that my constituents strongly support legislation and programs that recognize the rights of unborn Canadians. These are values, Mr. Speaker, that I share. These are values that I am honoured to express for the people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso. We regard the extent
November 19, 1984

of support for the handicapped, the elderly, the infirm and the defenceless as evidence of the real progress of our society.
The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso are independent. We are ordinary Canadians. We are proud to be led by the only Party in Canada that represents the ordinary Canadian. The Prime Minister and I have been honoured with the greatest PC vote ever in the history of Cape Breton High-lands-Canso. For this vote I am most grateful and I thank my constituents. My riding was represented just a few short months ago by the former Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon. Mr. MacEachen. He served his constituents and all Canadians with distinction. On behalf of the people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso it is appropriate that I acknowledge the contribution of Senator MacEachen and thank him for his years of service.
Cape Breton Highlands-Canso is a geographical, cultural and economic mosaic. It includes an important fishing industry with deep sea fleets sailing from Canso and Petit de Grat. These deep sea fishermen leave their families for a week or more to harvest the sea's bounty. It is hard work. These are independent persons who spend more of their adult lives at sea than on land. At the present time, they are struggling to make ends meet.
Many other constituents are hard working inshore fishermen who are also striving to meet the problems of their industry and to earn a living. These men are entrepreneurs. They own their boats. They risk their lives to make a living to provide for their families. These people talk straight. The people I represent need no education to identify hardship.
The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso have distinguished themselves as the best pulp and paper workers in this country and among the best woodsmen in Canada.
The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso enjoy one of the best public school systems in the world. Cape Breton Highlands-Canso is an area known for incomparable hospitality. This reputation greatly contributes to growth in our tourism industry. That is one reason, Mr. Speaker, that the Cabot Trail is one of Canada's leading tourist attractions. It is also a natural beauty surpassing in appeal any other attraction in Canada. The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso have distinguished themselves as tradesmen, small businessmen and farmers. We view offshore oil and gas development as an opportunity and are working hard to realize its potential.
Despite these strengths, Mr. Speaker, we have been plagued by successive years of high unemployment and outward migration. In the thirties, forties and fifties, Nova Scotians left to seek employment in the United States and Ontario. Later they left for western Canada. Today we find there is no place to go. It is, as never before, imperative that our strengths be fully developed, that we strive for self-sufficiency, and that we achieve self-sufficiency.
On a daily basis my office deals with requests from many constituents looking for employment. These are people with families, children and spouses and with bills they cannot pay. That is why I ran for office and why they elected me, Mr. The Address-Mr. O'Neil
Speaker. These people want jobs, and I am pleased that the Government has made job creation its priority.
On September 4, I was elected on a platform which called for the rejection of short-term make-work projects as an answer to unemployment. The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso have rejected make-work projects as a long-term solution. They want permanent, meaningful jobs. I am confident that the new Government can meet that challenge. Indeed, it has already begun the task.
In its Throne Speech, the Government identified our new approach. We are committed to getting this country moving quickly to achieve a new era of national reconciliation, to moving quickly to economic renewal, and to attaining greater levels of social justice.
I wish to congratulate the Prime Minister on his Cabinet selection. Nova Scotia's two Cabinet representatives, the Hon. Robert Coates and the Hon. Elmer Mackay, are distinguished parliamentarians and Nova Scotians. I am honoured to be here with them.
I have met with the Hon. Flora MacDonald, the Minister of Employment and Immigration. She has displayed an openness and empathy that was more than I could have anticipated. It is clear to all Canadians that she is a leader. I wish to congratulate the Prime Minister on his appointment of the Hon. Sinclair Stevens as the Minister of Regional Industrial Expansion. In our meetings, he too has displayed a driving commitment to developing areas most in need of economic activity. The Hon. Pat Carney, Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, has displayed a true commitment to East Coast energy development. The Hon. Minister of Fisheries (Mr. Fraser) has also shown himself to be interested in solving the serious problems of the East Coast fishery. As Canadians, we are most fortunate to have such talented individuals willing to serve us.
I have heard members of the Opposition complain that Cape Breton has no private sector economy. That is why the previous government was defeated. It was the previous government that left that legacy. I know that the people of that area of Canada can develop a self-sustaining economy. We in the Progressive Conservative Party have confidence in the people of Cape Breton Highlands Canso. We have begun the process of attaining that result.
Our Government has established a new Ministry of Forestry, headed by a distinguished New Brunswick Member, the Hon. Gerald Merrithew. This appointment reflects our Government's decision to enhance the development of a renewable resource. It will mean long-term benefits for the people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso. Our Government has established a new Ministry of Tourism headed by another distinguished Maritime Member, the Hon. Tom McMillan of Prince Edward Island. This commitment by our Government will result in a more rational development and orderly marketing of our tourism resources. That decision will result in an increased growth in our tourism sector.

November 19, 1984
The Address-Mr. O'Neil
Our Government has started the process of reducing our huge budgetary deficit. The people of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso realize that long-term economic security cannot be achieved simply by spending government money. Decisions to invest must have a rational business basis. My constituents know this better than any other group of Canadians because of the failure of northern Nova Scotia to establish a stronger economic base despite the input of large sums of government money.
The Prime Minister has confirmed the commitment of our Government to assist the needy. Ours is a government that is compassionate. The Throne Speech outlined the Government's commitment to the elderly, the disabled, the poor, to reducing inequality between the sexes, and to the preservation of our health care system. The Prime Minister has announced action on spousal allowances and veterans' benefits.
I am proud to be a Progressive Conservative. Our Party believes in sound management and compassionate leadership. I am proud to be led by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. He will be remembered as the Canadian leader who turned this country around and as a Prime Minister with the courage to lead.

In the case of Cape Breton Highlands-Canso, that will require that we stabilize our fishing industry, and that we fully take advantage of our marketing opportunities and fully develop our forestry sector. Our agricultural industry must also be protected because it too is a renewable resource. These sectors provide permanent jobs on which people must rely.
With respect to new industry, we have a magnificent harbour in the Strait of Canso.
